questions.stem: What is true about the zero exponent rule?

alternatives.text: The result is always 1.
The result is always 0.
Raising to the exponent 0 does not change the value.
Raising to the exponent 0 is an invalid operation.

questions.stem: What is true about raising to the exponent 1?

alternatives.text: The value is multiplied by itself one time.
The value does not change.
The result is always 1.
The result is always 0.

questions.stem: What does raising to an exponent mean?

alternatives.text: A value is multiplied by itself (n) number of times.
A value is multiplied by the exponent (x).
A value is added to by itself (n) number of times.
A value is added to by the exponent.

questions.stem: What is the difference between the product rule and the power of a product rule?

alternatives.text: The product rule is another name for the power of a product rule.
The product rule has different exponents and different bases, while the power of a product rule has different exponents with the same bases.
The product rule multiplies two values with the same base (but different exponents), while the power of a product rule multiplies two values with different bases (but the same exponents).
The product rule has the same exponents and the same bases, while the power of a product rule has the same bases with different exponents.

questions.stem: What does the negative exponent rule mean?

alternatives.text: Change the value into the fraction 1/x, with (x) being the original value.
Apply the exponent to the value, but always make the result negative.
Apply the exponent. The result will be positive if the original value was negative, and negative if the original value was positive.
Change the value into its reciprocal using a negative exponent.

questions.stem: What does power of a power mean?

alternatives.text: Two bases with the same exponents that are multiplied together, then raised to their shared exponent.
A value raised to the multiplication of two exponents.
An value raised to an exponent, then raised again to a different exponent.
A value raised to the addition of two exponents.
